awd_titl_txt: Spin Response in Organic Semiconductors with Tuned Spin-Orbit Coupling
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) and Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Programs, both in the Division of Materials Research. 

Non-technical Description: This project is on the physical properties of newly synthesized organic polymers that contain platinum (Pt) atoms at different intervals along the polymer chain. The intrachain Pt atoms substantially enhance the coupling between the spin and the orbital angular momentum of electrons in the polymer chain. This leads to a strong red phosphorescence emission, in addition to the blue fluorescence emission known from more common polymer chains without spin-orbit coupling. The combination of both types of emission mechanisms creates white light that can serve in newly developed white organic light emitting diodes, which may replace regular bulbs in the future. Through optical, electrical and magnetic studies of these polymers, a number of fundamental scientific questions are explored that can have important ramifications on potential applications of these materials. In addition, the integration of the large arsenal of experimental techniques within the research groups of the principal investigators serves to efficiently educate graduate and undergraduate students involved in this highly interdisciplinary research project. The educational aspects of this project are in particular open to collaboration with the ACESS program at College of Science of the University of Utah, which aims to enhance the involvement of women in natural sciences.

Technical Description: This research project is to study the spin-aligned carrier response as revealed by spin-pumping, spin-injection and spin-manipulation in newly synthesized pi-conjugated polymers with large spin-orbit coupling. In these polymers, Pt atoms are inserted into the organic building blocks at different intervals along the chain, which effectively tune the polymer spin-orbit coupling. The research uses a variety of novel optical, magneto-optical and electrical measurement techniques. The spin aligned carriers in Pt-polymers are polarized using the three effective techniques of spin polarization that include: spin injection by ferromagnetic electrodes, spin pumping by spin-waves in ferromagnetic substrates, and optical spin alignment by circularly polarized light absorption. The following processes are investigated: spin aligned carrier injection and transport in these polymers using the magneto-optic Kerr effect and magneto-electroluminescence; spin-current induced by spin-wave pumping in various ferromagnetic spin injectors; and photo-induced spin aligned triplet excitons. These studies contribute to the understanding of the physical processes that govern the spin response in organic spin devices, and have the potential to revolutionize their performance.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was the study of spin-pumping, spin-injection, spin manipulation and other spin-polarization and transport related phenomena in organic semiconductor materials with varying degree of spin-orbit coupling strength. Spin is a property of electrons that is responsible for the electron’s magnetic behavior. Spin-orbit coupling is the interaction between an electron spin’s magnetism and the electron’s motion in a material. Due to the large numbers of electron spins that are contained in materials, electron spin plays a major role in determining the material’s magnetic properties.

Intellectual merits of NSF Award #1404634

A variety of optical, magneto-optical and electrical techniques were used in this experimental research project. In addition, we also used a new experimental technique, namely the pulsed inverse spin Hall effect spectroscopy, which was developed to a matured measurement method on the basis of a demonstration that existed at the start of this project. The new technique allowed the characterization of a material’s capability to conduct magnetism in the form of spins, even if the material itself was not intrinsically magnetic. It was based on the generation of a pure spin-current (namely spin-current that does not involve charge current) in a non-magnetic material (e.g. an organic semiconductor), using microsecond short ferromagnetic resonant pulses that were imposed on an adjacent ferromagnetic material. The subsequent spin current detection was achieved by the inverse spin-Hall effect which converted the spin current into a charge current which, in turn, could be detected by electrical contacts. The inverse spin Hall effect is essentially another mechanism that allows to generate an ‘electromotive force’, like a battery, yet, unlike a battery, not from a chemical reaction but from a flow of magnetization. The materials structure that was used for pulsed inverse spin Hall effect spectroscopy is illustrated in Figure 1.

Using this technique, spin-current generation and spin transport effects were studied systematically on a variety of organic thin film materials based on different fullerene derivatives and π-conjugated polymers with varying degrees of intrachain platinum (Pt) density. Pt atoms can modulate the effective spin-orbit interaction in polymers. The strength of the spin orbit interaction determines the length that an electron’s magnetic moment can keep its alignment while it moves, the so-called spin diffusion length.  Also, the spin-orbit interaction strength affects the inverse spin-Hall effect magnitude. Consequently, this project allowed for a systematic exploration of spin-orbit related materials effects which, in turn, have given insights into the suitability of the studied materials for their applicability for spintronics devices. Finally, the study concluded with the discovery that the inverse spin-Hall effect can also occur when an organic ferromagnetic material is adjacent to a non-magnetic material.

This project supported the research activities of two groups at the University of Utah, as well as a variety of educational and outreach activities. Most significantly, the continuation and further development of an undergraduate recruitment effort was pursued. High school and middle school students from underrepresented groups were targeted to participate in so called “MESA (=Math, Engineering, Science Advancement) physics days” at the University of Utah’s Department of Physics and Astronomy (see photos of some of these activities in Figure 2). The outreach to specifically underrepresented groups was accomplished by collaboration with MESA clubs at local high schools and middle schools as these clubs are known to have above-average participation rates of students from underrepresented groups.

Broad impacts of NSF Award #1404634

Broad impact of this project was achieved in various ways: Firstly, through the successful establishment of a solid scientific foundation of the pulsed inverse spin-Hall effect spectroscopy which has already led to breakthroughs in materials research in the course of this project. Such discoveries are a prerequisite for the continued development of innovative nanoelectronic, spintronic and quantum devices. Secondly, through the training of highly qualified scientists and engineers who have become tenure track faculty at universities, work in research laboratories and in industry, and who have become driving forces behind innovation and economic progress in our society. Thirdly, broad impact has been also achieved beyond science and technology, namely through the outreach activities that were performed in the course of this project. Through this program we have also influenced individuals who may have chosen or will choose to get a college education in a STEM discipline. Consequently, the scientific, academic, and technological results of this project are likely to impact various aspects of human society and the wellbeing of human mankind, ranging from the impact that the trained and recruited students produce to the direct benefit of the research results that have been obtained in the course of this project.
